section.name: ENTREP THROUGH ACQUIS.: Entrepreneurship through Acquisitions
ENTREP THROUGH ACQUIS.: Entrepreneurship through Acquisitions

comments:
MGMT 811, Entrepreneurship Through Acquisition focuses on the theoretical and practical issues of acquiring a business. Topics include: locating a business, due diligence, reviewing and analyzing data, valuation, raising capital/financing the deal, structuring the acquisition, and integrating the target. The class consists of lectures, in-class discussions of caselets, assigned readings, homework problems, and a group project.  It is a half semester course.

All the students “really enjoyed” MGMT 811, and a few even found it “inspiring.”  Many praised the material for being “highly relevant and actionable” and appreciated the “very practical approach to the subject matter.”  A few noted how quickly the three hour lectures went, especially since they were divided up into “mini-cases in class, guest speakers, personal anecdotes, and an otherwise highly entertaining lecture style.”

All the students praised Professor Chalfin and loved the “wealth of experience” that he brought to the classroom.  Students felt that he “[embodied] the rare combination of actual experience and teaching prowess,” and most appreciated his ability to “apply concepts to the real world with cases and examples from his own experience.”  Several also mentioned that Professor Chalfin was “charismatic” and a “great lecturer.”

Most students made no comment about the workload, but one mentioned that the course had “just the right amount of work.”  While another mentioned wishing for “more guidance” on homework and a third felt that the TAs were narrow minded in giving points, students noted these only as minor complaints.  MGMT 811 is an MBA course that can be counted towards the Entrepreneurial Management and Management majors.  MGMT 801 is recommended as a prerequisite.
